description: From Old French, from Latin perplexus (“entangled, confused”), from per (“through”) + plexus, perfect passive participle of plectō (“plait, weave, braid”).

adjectives.description: perplex (comparative more perplex, superlative most perplex)

verbs.description: perplex (third-person singular simple present perplexes, present participle perplexing, simple past and past participle perplexed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to feel baffled; to puzzle.
(transitive) To involve; to entangle; to make intricate or complicated.
examples: What was thought obscure, perplexed, and too hard for our weak parts, will lie open to the understanding in a fair view.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To plague; to vex; to torment.
examples: Chloe's the wonder of her sex, 'Tis well her heart is tender, How might such killing eyes perplex, With virtue to defend her.
